Comment: What exactly is a “movie” in 2025?  Are we talking about something that spends X amount of time in theaters before going to streaming services? Are we talking about a production that is at least Y minutes long that is intended to be watched in a single session?  Is a production of similar length that is made by a streaming service and never sees a cinema a “movie”?  What’s the difference between a “TV show” and a “movie” in 2025?  For that matter, what about YouTube videos? Are they movies?  Say an American goes on a trip overseas, shoots some footage, gets back to the US, edits their footage into a video, uploads it to YouTube, and monetizes it. Is it tariffed?  What if they edit the footage and upload it overseas? Is that monetized?  If the footage has already been made (as of today) but is post-processed after tariffs go into effect, what then?  Just a few amongst many, many questions.
Author: racedownhill

Comment: The US film industry has actually been lagging the last couple years. There's been a sharp decline in the number of productions stateside, with a pretty large percentage of the work force unemployed and several large vendors shutting their doors from lack of work.  The Teamsters contract that was signed during the strikes really fucked up the budgets for US projects, as they already massively compensated transpo department managed to get significant increases which caused a cascading effect of productions needing to have cuts across all other departments to balance budgets.  Expiring state tax credits or reduced state tax credits have also seen productions leave the US for countries offering better tax credits.

Comment: "they want to force production to move back here without offering many incentives or investing in industries."  This is the main issue. Tariffs in themselves aren't necessarily bad, but they're meant to protect an existing industry with some encouragement to expand it.
